question.text: Mr. Meisel___to get to work early.

answer.explanation: (B) Habitual action is expressed by the present tense. Choices (A) and (C) are incorrect because “like” is a stative verb and therefore is not used with a continuous tense. Choice (D) does not agree with the subject.

question.text: The ticket holders may be___about the change in date.

answer.explanation: (C) The “change” is causing the ticket holders to be confused; use the past participle. Choice (A) is present participle. Choice (B) is base form. Choice (D) is present tense.

question.text: Mr. Carlo was very upset when he learned that he had been passed___for the promotion.

answer.explanation: (C) “Pass over” means “ignore” or “not choose”. Choice (A) would form “pass in”, meaning “submit”. Choice (B) would form “pass out”, meaning “distribute” or “ose consciousness”. Choice (D) would form “pass through”, meaning “go through”.

question.text: We have spent too much money and will have to ___ for the rest of the year.

answer.explanation: (B) The verb form is required here. Choices (A) and (C) are nouns. Choice (D) is an adverb.

question.text: Time is short and we will have to work very hard to___our goals by the end of the year.

answer.explanation: (D) “Achieve” means “reach”. Choices (A), (B), and (C) look similar to the correct answer but have meanings that don’t fit the context.

question.text: You can choose to have your paycheck mailed to you,___you can have your salary deposited directly into your bank account.

answer.explanation: (A) “Or” indicates a choice. Choice (B) indicates a condition. Choice (C) indicates a contradiction. Choice (D) indicates a result.

question.text: This building,___was built more than 100 years ago, is scheduled for demolition next month.

answer.explanation: (D) “Which” is a relative pronoun referring to the noun “building” and acts as the subject of the nonrestrictive adjective clause. Choice (A) is a pronoun, but not a relative pronoun. Choice (B) is a relative pronoun used in restrictive clauses. Choice (C) is a verb.

question.text: If you___your application tomorrow, you will still be eligible for the job.

answer.explanation: (C) This sentence is a future real conditional idea and requires a present tense verb in the if clause. Choice (A) is an infinitive. Choice (B) is past tense. Choice (D) is present tense but doesn’t agree with the subject.

question.text: We___in the elevator when the electricity went out, and we were stuck there for almost an hour.

answer.explanation: (B) The past continuous form indicates an action that was in progress when another action (the electricity went out) occurred. Choice (A) is simple past tense. Choice (C) is past participle. Choice (D) is past perfect.

question.text: You must___every item on the form or your application will not be considered.

answer.explanation: (A) “Must” is a modal so it is followed by the base form of the verb. Choice (B) is an infinitive. Choice (C) is a gerund. Choice (D) is future tense.
